newsitem.title: USA: US shares seen off with bonds after strong durables.
newsitem.headline: US shares seen off with bonds after strong durables.

text.p: A surprisingly strong July durables goods report sent bonds into a tailspin and will likely pressure U.S. stocks at the open on Friday but analysts still see the Dow pushing for a possible record close later.
"The tilt of the market is still up, but the durable goods number may take some of the energy from an upswing at the opening," said Alan Ackerman, a market strategist at Fahnestock and Co.
The long bond, flat ahead of the data, tumbled 19/32 to yield 6.89 percent. September S&P 500 index futures slumped 2.40 to 669.45, indicating the Dow may fall some 20 points.

July durable goods orders rose 1.6 percent, against expectations for a 0.3 percent advance. Ex-defence durable goods orders climbed 3.5 percent, compared with expectations for a 0.8 percent rise. June durables were revised up to a 0.2 percent drop from the previously reported 0.6 percent fall.

Tobacco stocks will again be a focus. President Clinton is expected to later announce a new series of restrictions on the sale and advertising of tobacco products in the biggest challenge to cigarette makers in over 30 years.
